articles.headline: Israel Says Its Military Is Starting to Shift to a More Targeted Gaza Campaign
articles.snippet: Israeli officials privately say that they hope to complete the transition by the end of January, but that the timeline could change.
articles.abstract: Israeli officials privately say that they hope to complete the transition by the end of January, but that the timeline could change.
articles.lead_paragraph: Israel said its military is starting to shift from a large-scale ground and air campaign in the Gaza Strip to a more targeted phase in its war against Hamas, and Israeli officials have privately told their American counterparts that they hoped the transition would be completed by the end of January, U.S. officials said.
articles.byline: By Patrick Kingsley, Adam Entous and Edward Wong

articles.headline: Far Right Balks as Congress Begins Push to Enact Spending Deal
articles.snippet: With little time to spare before a shutdown deadline, Speaker Mike Johnson will have to navigate the same political currents that did in his predecessor.
articles.abstract: With little time to spare before a shutdown deadline, Speaker Mike Johnson will have to navigate the same political currents that did in his predecessor.
articles.lead_paragraph: Congress on Monday began an uphill push to pass a new bipartisan spending agreement into law in time to avoid a partial government shutdown next week, with Speaker Mike Johnson encountering stiff resistance from his far-right flank to the deal he struck with Democrats.

articles.headline: Panel on Boeing Plane May Not Have Been Properly Attached, Agency Says
articles.snippet: The National Transportation Safety Board’s statement about the Max 9 jet that had a midair blowout came hours after two airlines reported finding loose parts on some Max 9s.
articles.abstract: The National Transportation Safety Board’s statement about the Max 9 jet that had a midair blowout came hours after two airlines reported finding loose parts on some Max 9s.
articles.lead_paragraph: Federal investigators said late Monday that it was possible that the bolts that were supposed to keep a fuselage panel in place were never installed before the panel blew off an Alaska Airlines Boeing 737 Max 9 in a near-disastrous accident on Friday night.
articles.byline: By Niraj Chokshi and Mark Walker

articles.headline: Why Iowa Turned So Red When Nearby States Went Blue
articles.snippet: Over the past 15 years, the Upper Midwest has seen a remarkable state-by-state sorting of voters along partisan lines.
articles.abstract: Over the past 15 years, the Upper Midwest has seen a remarkable state-by-state sorting of voters along partisan lines.
articles.lead_paragraph: With the Iowa caucuses days away, politicians will be crisscrossing the state, blowing through small-town Pizza Ranches, filling high school gyms, and flipping pancakes at church breakfasts.

articles.headline: JetBlue Chief Executive to Step Down
articles.snippet: Robin Hayes described the decision to retire as “bittersweet,” and suggested that unspecified health concerns had driven it.
articles.abstract: Robin Hayes described the decision to retire as “bittersweet,” and suggested that unspecified health concerns had driven it.
articles.lead_paragraph: The chief executive of JetBlue Airways, Robin Hayes, said on Monday that he planned to step down after nine years in the role and while in the middle of trying to carry out a merger with Spirit Airlines that could reshape the industry, if it isn’t blocked in court.

articles.headline: Israeli Strikes in Lebanon Kill Hezbollah Commander, Militia Says
articles.snippet: The latest strikes across Israel’s northern border came as the U.S. secretary of state made another trip to the Middle East in efforts to prevent a wider war.
articles.abstract: The latest strikes across Israel’s northern border came as the U.S. secretary of state made another trip to the Middle East in efforts to prevent a wider war.
articles.lead_paragraph: Israel launched strikes into southern Lebanon on Monday against Hezbollah, the Iranian-backed militia, which said one of its senior commanders had been killed there, adding to concerns that Israel’s fight against Hamas in Gaza could erupt into a wider regional war.
articles.byline: By Euan Ward, Isabel Kershner and Thomas Fuller

articles.headline: No, That’s Not Taylor Swift Peddling Le Creuset Cookware
articles.snippet: The singer did not promote a giveaway of the popular cookware, but an artificially generated version of her voice suggested otherwise.
articles.abstract: The singer did not promote a giveaway of the popular cookware, but an artificially generated version of her voice suggested otherwise.
articles.lead_paragraph: Taylor Swift’s affinity for Le Creuset is real: Her collection of the cookware has been featured on a Tumblr account dedicated to the pop star’s home décor, showcased in her gift choices at a fan’s bridal shower and shown in a Netflix documentary that was highlighted by Le Creuset’s Facebook page.
articles.byline: By Tiffany Hsu and Yiwen Lu

articles.headline: In the N.F.L. and at Big Companies, Diversity Playbooks Face Hurdles
articles.snippet: The league’s successes and struggles are playing out in hundreds of companies that have emulated its Rooney Rule in trying to hire more people from underrepresented groups.
articles.abstract: The league’s successes and struggles are playing out in hundreds of companies that have emulated its Rooney Rule in trying to hire more people from underrepresented groups.
articles.lead_paragraph: The end of the National Football League’s regular season on Sunday triggered the start of two annual events: the playoffs, and the period when a wave of teams fire head coaches and general managers and start frenzied searches for their replacements.
articles.byline: By Ken Belson and Jenny Vrentas

articles.headline: Lawmakers Push U.S. to Consider Trade Limits With A.I. Giant Tied to China
articles.snippet: A congressional committee made the demand of the Commerce Department after The Times reported on concerns among U.S. intelligence officials over the Emirati company, G42.
articles.abstract: A congressional committee made the demand of the Commerce Department after The Times reported on concerns among U.S. intelligence officials over the Emirati company, G42.
articles.lead_paragraph: A U.S. congressional committee has asked the Commerce Department to look into whether a giant technology company controlled by the ruling family of the United Arab Emirates should be put under trade restrictions because of its ties to China.
articles.byline: By Edward Wong, Mark Mazzetti and Paul Mozur

articles.headline: Appeals Court Seems Skeptical of Trump’s Immunity Claim
articles.snippet: A three-judge panel appeared unlikely to grant the former president’s request that it throw out federal criminal charges that he plotted to overturn the 2020 election.
articles.abstract: A three-judge panel appeared unlikely to grant the former president’s request that it throw out federal criminal charges that he plotted to overturn the 2020 election.
articles.lead_paragraph: A federal appeals court expressed deep skepticism on Tuesday about former President Donald J. Trump’s claim that he is immune from charges of plotting to subvert the 2020 election, suggesting that it is unlikely to rule in his favor on a central element of his defense.
articles.byline: By Alan Feuer, Charlie Savage, Eileen Sullivan and Glenn Thrush

articles.headline: To Win Iowa, Trump Turns to Allies Like Marjorie Taylor Greene
articles.snippet: With the former president busy defending himself in court from 91 felony charges, his campaign has deployed high-profile conservatives to help fill the gaps in Iowa.
articles.abstract: With the former president busy defending himself in court from 91 felony charges, his campaign has deployed high-profile conservatives to help fill the gaps in Iowa.
articles.lead_paragraph: Less than a week before Iowans decide whether to slingshot Donald J. Trump toward another presidential nomination, his schedule looks like this: Go to Washington for an appeals court hearing on Tuesday. Pop into Iowa for a Fox News town-hall event on Wednesday — and then make an expected return to court on Thursday, this time in New York.
articles.byline: By Michael Gold and Kellen Browning

articles.headline: A Glimpse Inside a Devastated Gaza
articles.snippet: In the ruins of two Gazan towns, New York Times journalists witnessed the sheer destruction that Israel’s war has wrought and the devastation of Hamas’s operations.
articles.abstract: In the ruins of two Gazan towns, New York Times journalists witnessed the sheer destruction that Israel’s war has wrought and the devastation of Hamas’s operations.
articles.lead_paragraph: For a few fleeting moments, the two-story house on the edge of Bureij, a ruined town in central Gaza, still felt like a Palestinian home.
articles.byline: By Patrick Kingsley and Avishag Shaar-Yashuv

articles.headline: Saudi-Israel Ties Depend on Steps Toward a Palestinian State, Blinken Says
articles.snippet: In meetings with Israeli leaders, the U.S. secretary of state held out the prospect of Saudi recognition to prod Israel to curb combat operations in Gaza and accept a path to Palestinian statehood.
articles.abstract: In meetings with Israeli leaders, the U.S. secretary of state held out the prospect of Saudi recognition to prod Israel to curb combat operations in Gaza and accept a path to Palestinian statehood.
articles.lead_paragraph: Antony J. Blinken, the U.S. secretary of state, and a Saudi ambassador asserted on Tuesday the possibility of diplomatic recognition of Israel by Saudi Arabia if the Israeli government alleviates the suffering of residents of Gaza and puts Palestinians on a path toward statehood.
articles.byline: By Edward Wong and Vivian Nereim
